Posted: April 20, 2016
												I will be honnest here, I am terrible at games like these and while I tried I simple failed to much so I proceeded to play this game with a trainer, though later on things get a bit more manageable when you start to unlock more things and gain more control over the fights. To me however what drew me to this game was a combination of art style and story. The overal main red line of the story is as to be expected one done many times over, it is hard to avoid and frankly the least important factor of the story. Now what made the story great for me are all the little bits, the mistakes you can make without knowing the way you see everything play out and than get that subtle hint that you could have done better. I think now I completed my first playthrough I will certainly do an other as I missed some side quests and I like to see if I can do better with some of the things I did. Overal I would recommend this game if it is up your ally gameplay wise and story wise. I certainly have no regrets and with 10 hour baseline time for a single quick play through which can be 15 hours or a bit more if you go into everything it is an overal enjoyable experience.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: April 17, 2016
												Dex is an action platformer set in a cyberpunk dystopian future where mega corporations rule the world with hackers rebelling against them. The setting is a bit reminiscent of the Shadowrun series, although not quite as gritty.There is a good mix of exploration, fighting, leveling, scavenging, story dialog and side quests. While no one element is ground breaking, the varied gameplay keeps the game engaging till the end.There are lots of choices but not much in the way of consequences. Save for some side quests needing to be completed a certain way for some achievements there really isn’t a huge difference in the outcomes of the different dialog choices other than getting slightly different responses and maybe a bit more or less EXP. The game can just be saved and loaded to see all of the different outcomes, I didn’t really see the point of playing through the game twice.-Playtime-A good 16 hours to complete the game with all side quests.-Achievements-Most of the achievements you will get just by progressing through the game normally. There are several for getting the “good” result of many of the side quests. With a guide for these I got 100% on my first play through.Recommended on sale.

content:
Posted: April 20, 2016
												Dex has been a very pleasant adventure from start to end so it's with a joyful heart that I am writing this review. I don't intend this to be a full-scale review so I will simply sum up what I liked and what I disliked:+ responsive, fast-paced, fun to play+ well-written scenario and dialogues+ rich background environement, both in texture details as in the narrative+ very successfully rendered atmosphere of the 80s-90s cyberpunk novels or graphic novels, without comprimising to much in favour of tasteless fan-service- don't think you can even begin to appreciate the game if you don't pay thorough attention to the side quests- main character lacks in psychology (OK i get it that you want some template any player can fill in, but the rebel/teenager attitude falls a bit short sometimes)- Cyberspace tasks too easy even with basic hacking abilitiesThis game is a must for any cyberpunk fan/maniac/nostalgicThis game should be given a shot if you'd like an immersive universe and story that seems to have a life of it's own but don't have too much time to play.

content:
Posted: July 10, 2016
												This game is simply awesome. Sure, it has flaws. The animation is really poor, sends us back to the glorious days of 16-bits consoles. Weapon choice is very limited (and if you're anything like me, you'll go melee most of the time anyway). There are some frustrating moments, especially during some hacking phases.But overall, the non-linear gameplay is outstanding, the characters, if a bit cliché, are well concieved, the story has some twists, the quests can be completed in different manners (it doesn't affect the main story, but it still is a nice touch)... The whole game feels like playing something out of a William Gibbson novel.If this didn't convince you, let me try this way : first time I started the game, I played 5 hours straight, paused to eat something, then 3 more hours. When I finished the game, I started another playthrough immediately to try other quests choices and the other ending (which was disapointingly lacking of details compared to the first one I tried), and even got to beat all the achievements, which is something I usually don't care about.Would I recommend the game ? Hell yes.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: May 8, 2016
												My first thought after five minutes was "oh my, I'm playing a platformer!" - but it's not. It's a side-slider, which means - two-dimentional graphics, which means - no pathetic 3D-models, but excellent 2D-graphics. I bought the game for its graphics and it did not let me down.So:+ aesthetics (already mentioned before) is done very thoroughly.+ a bunch of side-quests, maybe a bit straightforward, but they are!+ "slay, steal, speak" - it's not Fallout, of course - but who is? The means to achieve a goal are not radically different - but they are different, even the ways to fight. There are also choices in the end of most quests, and there are sometimes hidden choices, so — quite non-linear.+ the story, the plot. I cannot say it's striked me, but it is good.+ the hacking system is a well-thought-out mini-game.? the language is somewhat difficult for non-natives (well, it was difficult for me - so, I guess, I've missed some part of plot)? implants - they were good, but I guess I waited a bit more.? the story again. A bit swallowed at the end, or have I missed smth?? there is stealth, but as far as I get it you only obtain XP for quests and kills (and rarely find while hacking) - you lack progress if you sneak without killing.- endings: I'll pass spoilers here, but one of them just states "ok, the end" - no result, no epilogue, no "so, where does it lead?", other gives a very short epilogue. Ok, some questions that you meet in the very end — admit it, you could not possibly find the answers, but overall it still looks a bit cut-off.==================So, should you play it?YES, if:* you DO LOVE cyberpunk and its atmosphere,* you like story-driven games and don't mind, if you've already heard some its parts,* you prefer not-so-hard fighting systems without much of tactics.NO, if:* you prefer advanced tactical battles with lots of different weapons and fine points,* you don't like dialogues and texts and digging into story at all.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: August 18, 2016
												When I read some of the reviews before I purchased this game stating that this is one the best RPG games they've played, I was skeptic. After finishing the game in 22 hrs, I can relate to Paul Sweeney's quote: "You know you've read a good book when you turn the last page and feel a little as if you have lost a friend." And this is definitely not just a 'good' game, it's the best RPG game I've ever played. There, I said it.This game is certainly a William Gibson-esque reliving of the '80s cyberpunk outfit. The action, substance, intrigue-factor, progression, and variation of the story based on the player's choices are in equilibrium -- making this an authentic 'RPG' game, unlike some common so-called RPG games with messed up mechanics and usually follows an inescapable linear story. You may think 'side-quests' are optional on this game -- of course they are. But curiosity strikes iron and you'll end up wanting to finish all. So did I.I also like how they engaged some classic arcade elements and basic cryptography puzzles within a story-rich game. Need to say I recommend this? Okay, I recommend Dex.UPDATE: This game should get an "I've Lost A Good Friend" award.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 15, 2016
												Dex is an example of when a developer makes an RPG the right way.  So many new developers are focusing on the wrong features like multiplayer, free to play etc... that they forget what makes a good game.  Dex may not have those shiny graphics but it has a lot of heart and is up there with some of the best rpgs.  In Dex you get a large open world to explore filled with interesting characters, meaningful side quests and dangerous enemies and loot.  The Environments are beautiful and dripping with atmosphere.  Its the gritty dark cyberpunk setting you can expect.  Gameplay is fun especially the augmentation feature.  You ll start to become an aug addict very soon wanting the next awesome implant to make yourself a badass cyborg.  The story is great and makes you very invested in the characters struggles.  I have enjoyeed every moment of the 12 hours i put into the game without fail.  In conclusion buy this game.  Its a shining example of RPGS done right and can even be said to be better than some AAA titles.  I only wish there was more to play and cant wait to see what the developers do next.

content:
Posted: November 29, 2016
												Dex impresses with a creative combination of roleplay and platformer gameplay, paired with a great story, plenty liberties of choices (with a few consequences in game), wonderful soundtracks, lively environment and appealing 2D art, innovative ideas and a 2 in 1 games feeling. Even the cutscenes were created with a big portion of love.It was surprising to find far less platformer gamestyle than expected and alot more story / RPG elements. The fairly dystopic cyberpunk genre has been interpreted and implemented with rich content elements, not only plenty of notes / ingame e-mails to read.The controls require some accustomization but once the player gets the hang of it, gameplay itself becomes fairly smooth. Map handling and relocation spoil the player some in a good and bad way. Health and Focus are two attributes of the played character. Regaining points in these attributes is treated in a rather unusual way to other games. Once familiar with that, exploring the game world and story becomes a true pleasure for friends of darker settings.Dex and the developers of Dreadlocks gave little to no reason to complain. In my eyes, this game is an underrated masterpiece of the cyberpunk genre and it ignites fun to grab the old character sheets of pen & paper cyberpunk again.

												This was great. For you old timers out there, this has a distopian future atmosphere like the Sega Genesis Shadowrun game, Beneath a Steel Sky, or even Neuromancer (old Apple, and other platforms, game). Gameplay wise the game was actually quite fun - if a little rough around the edges.But more than anything, I loved the story here. content:
Posted: January 6
												Pretty competent game, nothing groundbreaking though. Not sure why everyone is complaining about the hacking, you can get away with throwing a few points into hacking early on, and once you have the pulsewave and dualshot (you can get them pretty fast) there is nothing difficult about it.Some complaints are the melee combat system being somewhat clunky, enemies have 'kick' moves they chain and it doesn't appear they can be staggerd in their animation. It's basically down to getting them by suprise and mashing X, whilst staying ahead of him. Ranged combat is ok, with the only problem (alteast on controller) being the lack of aiming sensitivity resolution.The soundtrack is pretty good, but the loops are not well implemented. You can clearly hear it looping.The singularity ending was a 5 second clip then credits, rather disappointing...But I enjoyed it, get it if you can. It's a solid 10-15 hours depending how much of a completionist you are.

												Dex is a very charming cyberpunk RPG. Not a masterpiece in storytelling nor gameplay, it still stands very well on its own. It has a satisfying wide range of sidequests, skill checks in dialogues, open world, enjoyable combat system and scratched my RPG itch. My only big gripe witht the game that it's only 20 hours long, instead of 40. Close to the end of the game I still wanted to play more and I guess that speaks well of the game I judged to be simply "okay" instead of "amazing".Even after half a year later I think back to Dex with an not insignificant amount of fondness and frankly absurd amount of longing. I very much hope for a sequel. This game has a lot of promise and I am very curious what the devs can do with the world of Dex.

One costume grants stealth after 6 seconds of no movement and does not break until you perform an action.  Moving does not break it.  Another allows you to block gun attacks with your normal block and the final costume passively fills your focus meter.I highly recommend this game and I look forward to the next offering from Dreadlocks.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: March 6
												Dex is a nice game by dreadlocks that you would be wrong to think its small and simple but in fact it has a few surprises along the way and results in a positive experience . First and foremost, i have to comment about the general recommendation about this game, wich is "if you loved flashback (the old game from delphine software) you would love Dex" well...i have to say, i liked Dex, but i don't think is that much similar to Flashback... it has the sci fy setting allright, and there are data cubes (?) but that's all there is about that, the stories are very different and the game itself, is very very different. For starters, Flashback was an action adventure platformer...and Dex is an action RPG . They are both good games but different.The story for Dex is good...i mean, its ok....well...maybe not perfect, but it does it's job. It starts very classical, then somewhat slows in the middle, with all the side missions and staf, and then by the end, it goes full speed and allthough it develops fully, it does so very fast just in the last few levels. For me story wise, it happened too much at the end (maybe wasn't necessary to be honest) The thing is, there were many "heavy dialog scenes" and normally thats allright..but in this game where the characters speak through avatars (like a profile picture, that maybe opens it's mouth, moves a little, and thats it)  the problem is, it doesnt have a great range of expression, so, basically you are stuck just hearing the voice, and that slows down game play a lot (comparing it to others part of the game)Speaking of other parts, the game has great gameplay elements. You have your main character, and the abilities tree, similar to for example mass effect or any other rpg in wich you choose how you want to develop your character... so for example when you progress and make main missions and/or side missions and activities you gain xp points and you choose what you want to develop, your hacking computer skills? your biological implants? (does all kind of things) or just want to be the strongest at fighting? or a professional weapons expert ? maybe a mix of several....So, that part of the game (the gaming part itself) is really well done, and it's fun, and it has some character progression, even though, its not a AAA game, it does a very good job and its pretty well polished.Along with the third person view in wich you encounter friendly characters, and fight enemies, you have cyberspace. In this mode, you enter a computer and have to deal with firewalls and virus and failsafe programs (in shooting style) like a sort of space shooter game, with different powers and settings. This mode is for the most part optional...but...you can use it as an alternative for fighting...because every person in the game has robotic implants, you can hack into their minds, and paralyze them, and you take it down without even fighting. In my case i choosed to  develop all my hacking skills, and none of the fighting ones. So every time i entered a scene, first i hack the security cameras, then i did the same with the torrets, and finally i started going stealth and hacking soldier's brains and paralyze them ...it was great! allthough you can't do that with every one of them, there are some soldiers wich are partially immune to your attacks and you have to take them down classical style (with some stealth and fight).Anyway, because of all this when you reach the end game where there are many heavy dialog scenes, it kinds of slows down a little too much, and it looses momentum and the story really is good but not THAT good that it needs so much turns and surprises at the end... but still...its a nice little game and i recommend it if you don't have anything more important to play, and even better if you like cyber punk sci fy games.

												I just finished the game, and I personally think this game shouldn't be reviewed unless you finished the game, because the strong point of this game is in its story.The fightings isn't masterfully designed but this game isn't really about the fightings. I recommend it.

content:
Posted: July 10, 2015
												I wrote a first review based on the early state of the game. My opinion was that the game was awful, buggy and really not worth our money. I recentely installed it once more, and I found the game to be OK. The pace of the action is not very good, and the game mechanics are not very deep; for instance, there is no real difference in fighting early ennemies and the most powerful ones. The same strategy is applied; you just need more punches. The hacking part is a bit more insteresting, although it will never rival with half-decent shooters... but at least, it offers a variation of gameplay. The quests are fun to do, although you can completely mess up with some of them by doing things far too early.The story is interesting. I have to admit I did not anticipate what happens. However, I hate the endings (plural). For a game that is mostly trying to tell a story (since the other aspects are not so great), I hoped for more narrative endings.Overall, the game is OK to play if you have nothing else to do and a few bucks to spend.

Posted: February 23
												If you're a fan of the cyberpunk genre, you NEED to check out this title. It's like playing a William Gibson novel. There is Corporate extractions, package couriering, hacking, cyberware mods, software upgrades, plus moral choices around every corner. Cyberpunk is so much more then hacking and cyberware, it’s the emphasis on technology in a class ruled multicultural society and this is what most games do wrong. However Dex with it’s simple 2D simple side scrolling game style, linear storyline and easy controls seems to capture the very essence of futuristic city life.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: April 24
												Dex is a free-roaming cyberpunk action-adventure, a bit like Deus Ex in 2D. You take the role of a seemingly average jane living in the urban mess known as Harbor Prime, who like many a cyberpunk protagonist, suddenly finds herself wanted by armed thugs working for mysterious corpro-government interests. Fleeing for her life into the streets, Dex meets an assortment of colorful characters and must aquire various gear and eventually cyborg implants to stay alive and ahead of the game. Flexible character progression allows for melee, gunfighting, hacking, persuasion and cyborg enhancements like super-jumps and cloaking. It's got pretty good music and notably, a free DLC that adds extremely useful alternate outfits, most notably a stealth suit that allows you to stay cloaked indefinately provided you do not reveal yourself by attacking or interacting with objects.
